question: Question_08
sols:
\textbf{For (a):} First we can rewrite this statement without the
symbols in slightly more meaningful English.

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\emph{For any prime number \textbf{m} and for any prime number
\textbf{n}, \textbf{m}+\textbf{n} is prime.}
\end{description}

This is clear false since adding two primes doesn't always give a prime,
for example 3+5=8.

\textbf{For (b):} we get

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\emph{for any prime \textbf{m} there exists a prime \textbf{n} such that
\textbf{m}+\textbf{n} is prime.}
\end{description}

For this to be true, it has to be true for any choice of prime
\textbf{m}. Consider for example \textbf{m}=7. Can we add a prime to
that number so that the sum is prime as well? There are two types of
primes: the even ones (actually, 2 is the only even prime) and the odd
ones. If we add 2 to 7, we get 9 which isn't prime, so that doesn't
work. If we add any odd number to 7, we get an even number (clearly not
2) so clearly not a prime either. So no prime can be added to 7 to make
it prime and hence the statement \emph{(b)} is false.

\textbf{For (c):} we get

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\emph{There exists a prime \textbf{m} such that for any prime \textbf{n}
we have \textbf{m}+\textbf{n} is prime as well.}
\end{description}

This is fairly similar to the statement \emph{(b)} except that here we
want to be able to always add the same prime to any prime to get a new
one. In other words, it is even harder to make this statement true and
hence it is false. Indeed, we showed above that no prime can be added to
7 to make it prime again, so here 7 is a case of a value of \textbf{n}
for which we show that no prime \textbf{m} would do the trick.

\textbf{For (d):} we get

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\emph{There exists a prime \textbf{m} and there exists a prime
\textbf{n} such that \textbf{m}+\textbf{n} is prime.}
\end{description}

This sounds much more reasonable and it is. This statement is true since
we can actually even show values of \textbf{m} and \textbf{n} that work.
Consider for example \textbf{m}=2 and \textbf{n} = 3. Then
\textbf{m}+\textbf{n}=5 which is prime. So such values exist and so
statement \emph{(d)} is true.

\textbf{Note:} actually in \emph{(d)}, you should easily convince
yourself that one of the prime has to be 2 and so the other has to be
what is called a \href{http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twin_prime}{twin
prime}, that is, a prime with the property that if you add 2 to it it is
prime as well (those are, except for 2 and 3, the closest primes you
might get and that's why we call them twin primes). For example, 5 and 7
are twin primes and so are 11 and 13; 17 and 19; 29 and 31. We do not
know if there are infinitely many twin primes but we suppose it is the
case (this is what we call the The
\href{http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twin_prime}{twin prime conjecture}).
hints:
Try to translate those \emph{symbolic expressions} into meaningful
English for a start.
